content.body: gah, it's too warm to sleep
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/1038191/google-homepage-not-valid-html/1044778#1044778
depending on how the page is built, I'm quite sure the performance of google could actually be improved by adopting a more standards based approach
I feel guilty for posting on the codec thread
I should have known better
othermaciej: I can't see what part of your message somebody could reasonably take issue with.
I think the hardware concern is a major concern
MikeSmith: I was just hoping that I wouldn't extend the flamewar
othermaciej: if you didn't post on the thread at all, your silence would be interpreted as a clear indication that you are indeed part of the conspiracy
obviously
I think it's high time I added some H.264 and Theora stuff to my wisdom generator
heh. looking at it now, I see that I already had the "the MP/LA Expert Group" in there
under the category "seemingly-benign-pawns"
ok, now with even more wisdom: http://logopoeia.com/wisdom/
well, slightly more
first hit: "the divine principle of time inequality is encoded in Anne van Kesteren's weblog."
though reading further it also says "the divine principle of time inequality is encoded in the Nag Hammadi Library"
"Eminent thinkers throughout history (Roy Fielding, etc.) agree that the divine principle of time inequality is the transcendental principle behind all creation" :p
is any spec responsible for XMLSerializer?
nope
:-( there should be
It turns out that MySpace uses it on HTML DOMs and makes expectations
maybe XMLSerializer and DOMParser can be snuck into Web DOM Core
what expectations do they have?
othermaciej: they expect no generated namespace declarations
where do they depend on that?
I think Safari would generate namespace declarations and so violate their expectation
they except h=h.replace(/<html>|<\/html>|<html\/>/gi,"")  to zap the root element tags
when updating status/mood
you're making it sound like their way to do status updates is a Rube Goldberg device
othermaciej: it is
if we want an good baseline video codec
and the barrier is the choices made by device manufacturers and their hardware suppliers
and their decisions are purely economic
how varied are the DSPs used in contemporary handhelds?
then the only practical way forward is to encourage the proliferation of content in an unencumbered codec, to tip that economic balance
so it seems to me that everyone who's interested in having a good baseline video codec should be encouraging that
including by supporting Theora wherever the device constraints do not apply
hsivonen: a lot are using these OMAP chips, but a lot aren't
just wondering if writing for a Nokia shipped TI chip results in any portability to whatever Apple uses in iPhone
I believe the answer is no
ok :-(
oh hey, gsnedders just invaded my inbox via our bug tracking software
welcome!
annevk2: I already made your point about vendor consensus!
therefore it's a good one :-)
is Web DOM Core a W3C deliverable already?
annevk2: mwhaha?
roc, teaches me to read the whole thread first (over and over again...) :)
this is why gmail is superior
hasn't read the whole thread but points out that Nokia ships Flash on Maemo
wonders what *that* does to battery life when watching YouTube
I guess I should measure
roc, congrats btw on Firefox 3.5, haven't tried the official release yet, but it sure seems like a great product
thanks
but 3.6prealpha1 is what the cool kids are using these days :-)
so I hear, with a certain pref turned on rather than off :)
roc: what exciting stuff is planned for firefox.next?
Henri's HTML5 parser is on trunk, I assume that's what Anne was referring to
hopefully we'll turn it on for FF.next
well, I'm sure we'll turn it on, the question is whether we'll turn it off after we see what it does to the Web :-)
hehe
multiple backgrounds is already on trunk
is there anyone looking at webforms stuff?
someone is looking at file upload
I'm not sure what that plan is
Jonas is working on XBL2, I suspect we may try to build new web forms stuff on top of that
<video poster> is on trunk
fun. text-indent makes WebKit indent the video controller
in both Chrome and Safari
lots of other stuff is going on
hmm. looks like Cortado doesn't work right in IE with two instances on the same page :-(
roc: sounds cool, I should start reading the mozilla planet again sometime
hmm. maybe I should try to get my blog feed on planet so that I could advertise the HTML5 parser once the Windows crasher patch and comment end bang state are in
how are Xiph Cortado and Wikimedia Cortado related? I suspect the Wikimedia Cortado worked better than the Xiph one in IE.
I think it's important to promote Ogg-only video also for IE, so that people don't need to use royalty-encumbered fallback formats, but it seems Cortado isn't quite ready for prime time
has anyone researched the h.264 patents to find out when they're all due to expire, which would make h.264 royalty free?
I checked the MPEG-LA patent list earlier, but they only mention the expiration dates for the few that already expired. The others just list patent numbers
Seeming the first draft was 1999, I would guess no earlier than 17 years after that
The final draft was 2003, so potentially 2020
hey, that's before 2022 :-)
the problem is that there will be an H.265 or whatever
hsivonen: yes, you should definitely be on planet.mozilla.org
roc, are you just speculating about h.265, or is there already work in progress?
I'm speculating
Lachy: "under study for potential development" according to wikipedia
has On2 said anything about why they made the VP3 stuff free but not VP6?
why wouldn't there be?
wonders if On2 will provide nicely packaged Theora encoding solutions
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/H.265
gsnedders, I thought the patent term was 20 years, not 17
Lachy: It depends on country. Don't expect me to remember the max :)

"Patents must be granted in all "fields of technology," although exceptions for certain public interests are allowed (Art. 27.2 and 27.3 [1]) and must be enforceable for at least 20 years (Art 33)." - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TRIPS#The_requirements_of_TRIPS
so that applies to all countries that have agreed with TRIPS
quick black-box poking suggests the XMLSerializer in WebKit is already an HTML serializer when applied to HTML
what's the right mailing list for XMLSerializer? www-dom?
I don't see how www-dom would be relevant
what ARIA cases is chaals referring to here: http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/www-dom/2009AprJun/0009.html ?
no idea. Unfortunately, he's not around for me to ask him
hsivonen: about XMLSerializer, lacking any better place, I'd say public-webapps,
MikeSmith: ok.
MikeSmith: btw, I ran the V.nu deployment script yesterday
hsivonen: cool
I'll see if I can get the W3C instance synced up too
Hixie, is QUOTA_EXCEEDED_ERR used in webstorage defined as a constant anywhere for DOMException?
does anyone here working on WebKit know if you enforce any disk quota limits for localStorage and sessionStorage?
I just tried testing it with an infinite loop that keeps storing data until it throws an exception, but it just kept going
Lachy: I've seen bugs to fix that
don't know if they're closed or not
Lachy: https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=22765
and https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=26155
Rik|work, ok. I'd recommend also setting a quota for sessionStorage
annevk2: yt?
annevk2: What's "ouch" about http://www.w3.org/TR/2004/REC-DOM-Level-3-Core-20040407/core.html#baseURIs-Considerations?
hmm. looks like Daily Motion has some borked browser sniffing
Telling me to install Firefox in order to see video without proprietary plug-ins
when I'm using Firefox
gsnedders, liveness
oops. I've overridden my User-Agent string
annevk2: Ah, OK. So nothing more.
maybe
Heh. Opera's the only browser that ever treats it as live, though we have bugs.
hsivonen, willing to write the spec for XMLSerializer and DOMParser?
annevk2: can't volunteer right now :-(
href in the DOM on HTMLAnchorElement doesn't give the absolute URL, right? The only way to get that is to recompose the decomposition attributes?
gsnedders: It gives the absolute URL
The spec says that it reflects the content attribute though…
Hixie?
gsnedders, yes, but it reflects a URL value
gsnedders, see the definition of reflect
annevk2: Ah, right. I need to actually read beyond the note
annevk2: The definition of reflect could be improved to note that there are special cases wwhere the behaviour is more complex
hmm, that's just an introductory note, it doesn't define anything
but euh, I'm not the editor :)
attribute [ReflectURL] DOMString src;
This indicates that the src DOM attribute reflects a content attribute
named src, but that the result is a completed URL, not the raw
attribute value:
I'd think you want [Reflect=URL]
'cause all "reflect" thingies have something in common, but some have specific types
(e.g. they all create a new content attribute if none exists)
annevk2: I guess they didn't do it that way maybe because of  [Reflect=URL] would imply there's a content attribute named "URL"
because they're also doing, attribute [Reflect=class] DOMString className;
I see
annevk2: Is there any spec which says http://t/imported/annevk/xml/xml-base/004.xht should pass?
Is Perl installed on OS X by default?
Hmm, sounds like it is
wonders why somebody gets a "perl: No match." error
Oh, it's because they're using csh and writing "[...]" on the command line
Lachy: web dom core iirc

for a while at least

heh

rel values needs some more coordination prolly
